title: Prepare Your Portfolio For MASSIVE Deflation

transcript.text:
Tech investor Marc Andreessen, says that 
artificial intelligence is about to make

everything so cheap that it's going to break 
the economy. Amazon now runs over $520,000

AI-powered robots in its fulfillment centers. 
Walmart saves roughly $1.5 billion a year with

AI-driven inventory management. And Maersk 
has cut vessel idle time by 30% using AI. Now,

these all sound like good things, but experts have 
been warning that this is going to lead to massive

deflation. What if that happens? How would your 
portfolio be impacted? Is deflation good or bad?

I'm going to answer all those questions today 
using simple terms. So, let's get started. Now,

the prices of things go up over time consistently. 
It's called inflation. And the generally accepted

average for inflation is 3% a year. So the stock 
market returns about 9% per year and inflation at

3% nullifies some of those gains. So that means 
that the real returns for the stock market are

about 6% per year, adjusted for inflation. When 
the rate of inflation goes up, the price of goods

goes up. That becomes more noticeable. People 
start to complain. And everyone in the USA right

now is complaining about the prices of goods 
going up. So are they actually going up? Well,

we use a metric called the Consumer Price Index 
to measure this over time. It's a widely accepted

metric that economists use to gauge the rate of 
inflation. And as you can see here, it's about 3%.

And there's a number of categories here. You see 
Food and Energy, and these all other items bucket,

which is quite a lot more elaborate than I 
thought. And you can Google this and go look

at the data yourself. But you can see here they 
provide a table that shows the rate of inflation

for every single subcategory. And there's actually 
a geographic structure and an item structure. Here

you can see there are eight major groups and some 
examples of the categories that can be found in

each group. So there's a lot of stuff being 
measured here. And when we look at that rate

of inflation over time, you can see from May 2008 
till July 2008 that inflation was increasing. So

it peaked there at about 5% and then it started 
falling. So the rate of inflation was falling

year-over-year. That's called disinflation. So 
the rate at which inflation increases slows.

And then you can see when the rate of inflation 
actually goes negative. That means that prices are

cheaper than they were a year ago. That's called 
deflation. And it's actually not a good thing. But

the good thing about deflation is that it doesn't 
last very long. And here we've zoomed out. This is

a great chart. Simple. Shows the rate of inflation 
from 2005 until 2025. And the gray on the chart

shows the recession between 2007 to 2009, which 
was very dramatic. That's when I started my career

on Wall Street. Everything was all scary and you 
can see that short period of deflation. And then

when you look more to the right, you see that 
other gray line that represents the brief COVID

19 recession. I don't think you could really call 
that even a recession, but they do. And then you

can see now that inflation has settled around 3%, 
it's sort of around the average. Now when we look

at historical precedents for deflation, the most 
dramatic deflationary period in US history was

actually the Great Depression. It was between 1930 
and 1933. The second most dramatic deflationary

period was the 2007 and 2009 period referred 
to by economists as the Great Recession. And

during both of these events, unemployment spiked 
dramatically. Okay. Now, was it the unemployment

that created the deflation? In other words, fewer 
people are buying goods, the demand dropped,

so prices drop. Or was it that deflation, the 
prices dropping, resulted in unemployment? Well,

it's largely believed that recessions caused both 
deflation and unemployment. However, this time

they're expecting deflation to be caused by the 
most disruptive technology of our time, artificial

intelligence. It's largely believed that the 
dramatic AI efficiencies that we're seeing,

such as the examples given at the beginning of 
this presentation, are going to cause the price of

things to drop dramatically. Now, you could argue 
here that the big bad corporations are going to

be taking these excess profits and that the price 
cuts will never be passed on to the consumers, but

that's really oversimplifying things. But let's 
go ahead and assume that corporations are going

to become enormously profitable from the use of 
AI for automation. How can we measure that? Well,

there's a metric called Corporate Profits as a 
percentage of GDP and it's already at historical

highs. So, companies, as you can see in this 
chart, are already highly profitable. Now, this is

from 1940 to 2024, but the most recent measurement 
is around 11%. So, it roughly lines up with what

this chart shows you. And again, the gray bars are 
showing us recessions. And what this would tell us

is that the rich forward price to earnings ratios 
that you see out there, let's say on average

they're rich, right? Those can be justified based 
on the expectations of all the efficiencies that

are going to be created. But there's some big 
concerns around that because, turns out, AI isn't

coming for the 3Ds, the dirty, dull, and dangerous 
jobs. It's coming for white collar jobs. So the

impact is going to be far more pronounced since 
these folks have much higher purchasing power

right now. High unemployment leads to deflation 
because it causes a decrease in overall spending

which puts a downward pressure on prices. This can 
create what they call a deflationary cycle where

lower demand leads to lower prices which causes 
businesses to cut wages or layoff workers. Make a

note of the layoffs. We're going to talk about 
that in a second. And the cycle keeps getting

worse and worse. Now, indeed, some of this appears 
to be happening. And this recent article by CNBC

raised some eyebrows. So, job cuts in October hit 
their highest level for the month in 22 years.

There's this firm called Challenger. They monitor 
this stuff over time. It's all rather interesting.

You ought to pop open the report and take a look 
at it. Or actually, I'll do that for you. Show

you some of the more interesting parts. So they 
said that this is now the worst year for layoffs

since 2009, right? The great recession. And they 
say this is because a disruptive technology is

changing the landscape. So you can see this table 
here. The first four columns show each quarter for

the given years. And the last column there simply 
sums them. And through October of this year,

employers have announced over a million job cuts. 
This is an increase of 65% from the first 10

months of last year. And when you look at 2007 and 
2008, you see these large job cuts that happened.

And then of course in 2020, the pandemic, right, 
brought out a bunch of job cuts during that

short-lived recession. And now we're on track to 
exceed a million, perhaps hit the numbers that we

were at in 2008 and 2009. Now, you can contrast 
these numbers to the total unemployed people,

which as of August 2025 in the United States was 
around 7.38 million. So you're simply adding to

that number and there are of course folks 
that will get rehired but that might start

to become difficult because there aren't going 
to be that many open jobs with AI creating so

many efficiencies. Now one thing to note about 
these numbers is when you dig into them you see

that there's actually a root cause here that is 
only recently arrived and that is DOGE. So if

you look at the layoff location you see District 
of Columbia. Look at how dramatic that is. So,

you had what 35,000 job cuts year-to-date in 2024 
and over 300,000 year-to-date this year. And the

other thing that backs this up is when you look 
at the leading reason for job cut announcements

in 2025, it's DOGE Impact. And look at this. Very 
cool. They provide a breakdown of the job cuts by

reason. So, Doge is sort of a one-off, right? 
That's the US government's attempt to create

efficiencies in the government. Then of course 
the second leading cause here, market economic

conditions, the old macroeconomic headwinds 
blowing stuff right and then look further down

the list, you have artificial intelligence. Now 
if you're going out and aggregating all this data,

companies aren't going to be coming right out 
and saying well AI created all these efficiencies

necessarily because there's going to start to be 
public backlash around that. So whilst they want

to let investors know, hey, we're using AI and 
creating all these efficiencies, they have to

be very careful there because then when they talk 
about job cuts relating to AI, and people aren't

going to find that so palatable. And interestingly 
enough, there's a new bipartisan bill that would

require companies to report AI job losses. I 
only wonder how effective that's going to be when

you think about how corporate America operates. 
There's a lot of ways that you can spin job cuts

without having to put them into this bucket. I 
don't know what you would do with this information

necessarily. Perhaps it would just reinforce the 
fact that AI is taking a whole bunch of jobs. Now,

we've talked about this before and perhaps one of 
the biggest concerns that we have around AI is the

impact of very high levels of unemployment coming 
off the back of all these efficiencies being

created. You can only retool people so much. And I 
think that you'll probably see the effects of this

start to manifest themselves in overseas locations 
where people are less likely to complain. Think

Manila and Mumbai, right? Large offshoring 
centers will be hit quite hard. Maybe it would

be interesting to look at unemployment numbers 
over there. But for right now, we're interested

in what's happening in our own backyard. And here 
you can see that recessions, as I said before,

always create unemployment. And this unemployment 
manifests itself with very dramatic spikes. And

when we look at an unemployment in this five-year 
range, we see it slowly increasing and one wonders

if that's going to start increasing at a higher 
rate because it's going to be more difficult

finding a job once you're laid off. So just some 
thoughts here. They say that you should study

economics because when when you inevitably end up 
in the employment line, at least you'll understand

why you're there. Economics is one of the few 
professions where you can talk about money without

ever having to make any money. They say it's the 
only field where two economists can win the Nobel

Prize for saying exactly the opposite thing. 
Economists also create a lot of noise. I think

for retail investors, the minimum information 
you ought to know is inflation. You ought to

understand how that works because it's very 
important when it comes to planning. the simple

rule that your purchasing power halves every 30 
years. That's pretty important. So if you're on a

fixed income and you're 65 years old, by the time 
you get to 95 years old, your quality of life is

halve that's not very good, right? That's not the 
golden years that you were promised. So I think

that having a basic understanding of economic 
indicators lets you understand financial news,

hold better conversations. I certainly admire 
economists for their ability to analyze

the market in a manner that's actually quite 
sophisticated. There are a lot of moving parts,

a lot of variables becomes very difficult to 
navigate in a hurry. So we summarize so far.

Inflation is probably one of the most important 
metrics for retail investors to understand, as

is disinflation, right? And deflation. Right now 
the rate of inflation seems to be about average.

it's sort of flatlined. And that means that goods 
are constantly getting more expensive over time,

just at a slower pace. Let's say an average pace. 
However, when goods become cheaper over time,

these short-lived events have largely surrounded 
economic turmoil. You have to be very careful you

don't fall into the deflationary cycle we talked 
about. So obviously the question is how does this

impact your portfolio? And the question you might 
ask there is, well, what assets act as a hedge

during deflationary periods? We already know that 
the stock market's going to be performing horribly

during periods of high unemployment and deflation, 
right? What assets don't perform horribly? Well,

obviously cash is the simplest hedge against 
deflation because cash is really strengthening

in terms of the amount of goods that you 
can buy with it, right? And of course,

investment bonds. So bond prices rise as interest 
rates fall and they're falling right now, right?

Central banks are often prone to cut rates to 
combat deflation, so high quality fixed rate bonds

would be a good hedge. There's a lot of reasons 
to own bonds. You know, people always joke,

well, this is return-free risk. Yeah. Well, 
it's part of a well diversified portfolio,

and this becomes more important as you age. And 
even for younger people, this is going to help

reduce the extent to which you see your assets 
draw down during recessionary periods, which can

be very difficult for some to manage. As you know, 
people feel the pain of losses twice as much as

they feel the enjoyment of gains. And I think that 
in a market where most of the younger investors

today have never felt pain, that that perhaps the 
pain is three times as much. And then here they

talk about defensive stocks with strong dividend 
histories. That leans right into our Quantigence

strategy which focuses solely on companies with 
strong dividend histories. They say here cash-rich

companies with low debt thrive. That's because 
if you're holding debt in a deflationary period,

that's not a good thing. And then when it comes 
to gold, right, through traditional safe haven,

results vary. Now, inevitably, somebody will 
bring up, you know, digital gold, Bitcoin, which

doesn't have a history that's long enough for us 
to do proper correlation analysis, but certainly

that's an alternative asset class, and those can 
be useful to hold as well in small quantities. So,

what to do? Well, you probably watched this 
video because you're concerned about something

bad happening. Now, from our perspective, we're 
pretty entrenched in those assets I just talked

about. So, we're not very worried about any sort 
of deflation or recession that's coming up. We

sleep very well at night. Now, what happens when 
people get worried, and I see this all the time,

is they get tempted to modify their investment 
strategies in response to market events. I can't

tell you how many people talked about going to 
cash during Trump's tariff drama. Don't react

to market events. Have a strategy that you apply 
regardless of what the market is doing. Probably

the most important thing to be watching here is 
whether AI is going to threaten your income, your

job. Now, we covered that in this next video which 
talks about which jobs will likely be replaced

by AI. You should give that a watch next. Thanks 
so much for taking the time to watch this today.
